tit.e: Dainenbutsu Kyogen (comic pantomime to teach Buddhism to the public and accompanied by drums and gongs)
Dainenbutsu Kyogen (a comic pantomime to teach Buddhism to the public, accompanied by drums and gongs)
tit.cmt: タイトルなので補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 大念仏狂言（だいねんぶつきょうげん）とは、融通念仏宗（大念仏）の中興者である円覚上人による念仏の教えを無言劇としたもの。
sen.e: Dainenbutu kyogen is the silent play created from the teachings of Yuzu Nenbustu (reciting the name of Amida Buddha) sect (Dainenbutsu) reflourished by Enkaku.
Dainenbutu kyogen, a silent play created from the teachings of the Yuzu Nenbustu (reciting the name of Amida Buddha) sect (Dainenbutsu), was revived by Enkaku.
Dainenbutsu kyogen, a silent play created from the teachings of the Yuzu Nenbutsu (reciting the name of Amida Buddha) sect (also known as Dainenbutsu), was revived by Enkaku Shonin.

sen.j: 融通念仏は、摂津国の大念仏寺（大阪市平野区）を根本道場として良忍（聖応大師）によって始められたもので、その教えを広めるべく作られた念仏狂言。
sen.e: Yuzu Nenbutsu was started by Ryonin (Shoodaishi) and is a Nanbutsu Kyogen (Japanese play) created to spread its teachings with the Dainenbutsu-ji Temple (Hirano Ward, Osaka City) in Settsu Province as a base.

Yuzu Nenbutsu was started by Ryonin (Shoodaishi) and is a Nanbutsu Kyogen (Japanese play) created to spread its teachings, with Dainenbutsu-ji Temple (Hirano Ward, Osaka City) in Settsu Province serving as a base.

Yuzu Nenbutsu was started by Ryonin (also known as Shoo Daishi) and is a Nenbutsu Kyogen (Japanese play) created to spread its teachings, with Dainenbutsu-ji Temple (Hirano-ku Ward, Osaka City) in Settsu Province serving as a base.

sen.j: 京都の清凉寺や壬生寺などで融通念仏が盛んになり、壬生寺や清凉寺、千本閻魔堂、神泉苑には円覚上人による大念仏狂言が伝えられている。
sen.e: Yuzu Nenbutsu became popular in Seiryo-ji and Mibu-dera Temples in Kyoto, and Dainenbutu Kyogen of Enkaku was passed down in Mibu-dera Temple, Seiryo-ji Temple, Senbun Yenmado, and Shinsenen.
Yuzu Nenbutsu became popular in the Seiryo-ji and Mibu-dera temples in Kyoto, and Dainenbutu Kyogen of Enkaku was passed down at Mibu-dera Temple, Seiryo-ji Temple, Senbun Yenmado and Shinsenen.

Yuzu Nenbutsu became popular in the Seiryo-ji and Mibu-dera temples in Kyoto, and Dainenbutsu Kyogen of Enkaku Shonin was passed down at Mibu-dera Temple, Seiryo-ji Temple, Senbon Enmado and Shinsenen.
